content.description:
Fun and well featured. Certainly worth throwing some pads down.

Start squatting with both hands on a sidepull in the crack and work your way through the yin-yang crack to a mellow top out. Outstanding rock quality

Crux seems to be around the 3rd or 4th move, once you get your right hand to a big gaston where the crack widens up. Proper footwork will get you up and over.
content.protection: one or two pads is just fine. flat landing
content.location:
About 100 yards(maybe less) north of the Loaf Boulder.

You'll see a big triangular shaped boulder with a tall slab facing east.

The climb starts on the north side(facing away from camp) and gets shade just about all day long.

Downclimb the right side of the boulder

content.description:
If you're at the furthest end of the Candyland area, you just might run into Jesus.

This is 100% a classic Ibex line, and would get much more attention is it wasn't out in the middle of nowhere.
content.protection: A few pads are fine. Perfectly flat landing
content.location:
If you walk straight through Candyland, it's hard to miss.

Jesus sits within a cluster of 2 or 3 other boulders, and faces uphill at the end of the boulder field.

You can begin sitting at the base of the prow for the v8, or the standing start for a v6/7.

content.description:
Perhaps one of the most amazing novelty problems you'll ever climb.

This peculiar boulder has you start on a giant undercling inside the "cave" about head height. The top? The small hole at the top of the boulder.

Looks like its a tight fit, and believe me, it is. Just think thin and squirm your way out!
content.protection: just a pad is probably fine. You'll probably want to stand back and take come pictures
content.location:
Down the hill from the Pyramid boulder(looks like a volcom stone).

The opening of the boulder faces east.
